Why dislike winter? Well, for starters, snow. It just sucks. Shitty powder everywhere that gets into your shoes and melts, and it's hard to walk through it, and you don't know if you're walking on the sidewalk or in the middle of the street.

Secondly, cold. It's like thousands of little tiny spears being shot at you at high speeds. Why? Because it is literally tiny little ice particles being blasted at you that go through your clothes and sting you anyway.

Thirdly, I rarely experience daylight during the winter. Heard of the term winter depression? It is actually a medical problem caused by the lack of sunlight in the north during winter.

There is nothing romantic about winter except for when the snow is really really dense and you can't see five meters ahead. It's like no matter where you go it's your own little private sphere. But even that is bad because you know it will just add to the pile that's already there.

There are many reasons why I prefer winter, the most prominent reason is more pockets.

You almost always carry these three basic things: Keys, Wallet, Phone.
In summer shorts you have two pockets, you can't put the keys and phone in the same pocket because it scratches. You settle with phone and wallet in the same pocket but it leaves a big bulge.
Inevitably you're going to spend money (damned ice cream) and acquire coins, this adds further fuel to the problem. You don't want your coins and phone in the same pocket, but if you put them in with the keys you sound like Santa walking down the street, all jingly and shit.

You don't encounter these problems in winter, all these extra garments provide more than sufficient amount of pockets.

OK.  I have a question I'd like answered, and I think it might make a good video.  

We know that the two solstices and equinoxes each year are important milestones related to the seasons.  But why do we consider seasons to START on those days.  (And when did we start to consider it that way?)  In my humble opinion, the solstices and equinoxes should mark the MIDDLE of each season.  In other words, summer should start around May 6, and fall should start around Aug 6.  

Of course it's still pretty warm in early Aug, but that's when things start to change.  And if winter starts Nov 6, it's not already bitter cold, but its starting to be.  As it is now, many locations go through at least a month of very cold temperatures before winter even starts.

The main advantage, or course, would be to bring our cultural expectations for the seasons back in line with when they actually occur.  Summer would truely be the season of the sun as it would capture the three months when the sun is brightest.  Winter would be the season of night, and fall and spring would be the time of transition.

Anyway, I'm sure I'm not the first one to think along these lines.
